awd_titl_txt: Regularity, Stability, and Turbulence in  Fluid Flows
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance the knowledge of physical models which are of fundamental importance in engineering, meteorology, or natural disaster, such as flooding and hurricanes. It will advance the development of powerful mathematical tools based on state of the art analysis, and the theory of linear and nonlinear partial differential equations. An important component of the project concerns the training and mentoring of a new generation of scientists and researchers. The research program provides ample opportunities for Ph.D. students and Postdocs to be trained in mathematical analysis and physical modeling applied to fluid mechanics. 

This project uses powerful mathematical tools to tackle several fundamental questions on the behavior of flows in fluid mechanic. A rigorous theory will be developed to study how incompressible flows become linearly unstable close to possible blow-up time, a typical signature of turbulence. The effect of boundaries on the dynamic of incompressible flows is of paramount importance. It will be thoroughly investigated on the 3D quasi-geostrophic equation, a model used in meteorology and oceanography.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has harnessed the power of partial differential equations (PDEs) to advance our understanding and modeling capabilities of fluid mechanics dynamics. The development of PDE theory within this context is pivotal for studying intricate fluid behaviors, including the emergence of instabilities and irregular patterns commonly associated with turbulence. Such insights are of paramount importance in fields like weather forecasting and climate modeling.


The research activities undertaken in this project have yielded innovative mathematical tools tailored to address fundamental questions surrounding flow behavior in fluid mechanics. These investigations have led to a deeper understanding of the interplay between instabilities and the formation of irregularities in flows governed by the incompressible Euler equation. Furthermore, we've expanded the frontiers of PDE theory in the context of fluid mechanics with an emphasis on boundary effects. These effects are known to induce irregularities within the flow and are instrumental in the genesis of turbulence. Our work has extended this theory to the 3D quasi-geostrophic equation, a critical model in oceanography and meteorology.


A central aspect of this project has been the training and mentorship of the next generation of scientists and researchers. We have actively engaged in the education of Ph.D. students and Postdocs, providing them with expertise in mathematical analysis and physical modeling within the context of fluid mechanics. Moreover, the research stemming from this project has served as the foundation for lectures, mini-courses, and graduate-level topic courses offered by the Principal Investigator, ensuring the dissemination of knowledge and the cultivation of future scientific talent.
